Literature Review: Single-particle cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) has emerged as a powerful technique for determining the three-dimensional structures of biological macromolecules and protein complexes. Over the past decade, cryo-EM has undergone a remarkable transformation, evolving from a method primarily used for low-resolution structural studies to one capable of achieving near-atomic resolution. This revolution in structural biology has been driven by advances in both hardware and software, leading to an exponential increase in the number of high-resolution structures solved annually.The history of cryo-EM can be traced back to the 1970s when Jacques Dubochet and his colleagues developed the technique of vitrification, which allowed biological samples to be preserved in a near-native state for electron microscopy analysis (Dubochet et al., 1988). This breakthrough laid the foundation for modern cryo-EM, as it enabled the visualization of biological specimens without the need for staining or fixation.In the early days of cryo-EM, the resolution of structures was limited to 10-20 Å, which was insufficient for detailed molecular interpretations. However, the introduction of direct electron detectors in the early 2010s marked a turning point in the field (Kühlbrandt, 2014). These detectors offered superior sensitivity and speed compared to their predecessors, allowing for the collection of high-quality images with reduced beam-induced damage. This technological advancement, coupled with improvements in image processing algorithms, led to a dramatic increase in the resolution of cryo-EM structures.The development of motion correction algorithms further enhanced the quality of cryo-EM data by addressing the issue of beam-induced motion during image acquisition (Brilot et al., 2012). These algorithms allowed for the alignment and averaging of multiple frames within a single exposure, resulting in sharper images with improved signal-to-noise ratios.Another significant milestone in cryo-EM was the introduction of maximum likelihood-based image processing methods, such as those implemented in RELION (Scheres, 2012). These approaches revolutionized the way cryo-EM data was analyzed, enabling more accurate particle alignment and classification, and ultimately leading to higher-resolution reconstructions.The impact of these advancements was profound, with cryo-EM structures reaching resolutions below 3 Å becoming increasingly common. This 'resolution revolution' opened up new possibilities for studying challenging biological systems, including membrane proteins, large macromolecular complexes, and conformationally heterogeneous samples (Cheng, 2015).Despite these remarkable achievements, cryo-EM still faces several challenges and limitations. One of the primary obstacles is sample preparation, which remains a critical bottleneck in many cryo-EM studies. The process of vitrification can be unpredictable, often resulting in non-uniform ice thickness and particle distribution. Improvements in grid preparation techniques, such as the development of self-wicking grids and automated vitrification devices, are actively being pursued to address these issues (Noble et al., 2018).Another significant challenge in cryo-EM is the accurate determination of particle orientations, particularly for small proteins and those with high symmetry. This problem is exacerbated by the low signal-to-noise ratio inherent in cryo-EM images. Ongoing research in machine learning and artificial intelligence-based approaches for particle picking and orientation determination holds promise for overcoming these limitations (Zivanov et al., 2018).The quest for atomic resolution in cryo-EM has also brought attention to the impact of optical aberrations on image quality. While current microscopes are capable of achieving sub-2 Å resolution, realizing this potential requires meticulous alignment and correction of optical aberrations. Recent developments in automated microscope alignment and in situ aberration correction are addressing this challenge (Nakane et al., 2020).Looking to the future, several areas of development are likely to further enhance the capabilities of cryo-EM. The integration of complementary techniques, such as focused ion beam milling for in situ structural studies, holds great promise for expanding the range of biological systems that can be studied (Schaffer et al., 2019). Additionally, the development of time-resolved cryo-EM methods may enable the visualization of dynamic processes and transient states in macromolecular complexes (Fu et al., 2019).Improvements in detector technology, including larger and faster detectors, are expected to increase data collection efficiency and enable the study of even more challenging specimens. Furthermore, advancements in computational methods, particularly in the areas of machine learning and high-performance computing, are likely to push the boundaries of what is achievable with cryo-EM data processing (Punjani et al., 2017).In conclusion, single-particle cryo-EM has undergone a remarkable transformation in recent years, establishing itself as a powerful tool for high-resolution structural biology. While challenges remain, ongoing developments in both hardware and software continue to expand the frontiers of what is possible with this technique. As cryo-EM continues to evolve, it is poised to provide unprecedented insights into the structure and function of biological macromolecules, furthering our understanding of fundamental biological processes and potentially aiding in the development of new therapeutic strategies.
